testimony.threat_quote: que c'estoit eulx qui luy donnoit ung mauvais fame, que c'estoit ung beau chappeau qu'ils mettoient sur la teste de ses enfans que c'estoit assé pour la faire devenir genoxe et que sy il luy survenoit quelque chose qu'elle en donneroit la charge a luy deposant

immediately became ill, refused all food, died in a week

testimony.threat_quote: threatened to throw a stool at her head, calling her witch

testimony.quarrel_subject: dispute over a goose which her children thought was theirs

testimony.threat_quote: accused called on daughter to bring axe to kill him

ill for 3 months, spitting blood, stomach swollen, difficulty breathing; recovered after cure advised by accused

harms_alleged.harm_description: such unpleasant illness they could not be eaten, had to be killed; everyone judged them bewitched

testimony.quarrel_subject: accused came to say she did not want her son to frequent witness's daughter or marry her
could not agree on price for reaping work - wanted a gros more per journal

harms_alleged.harm_description: child disappeared in open field, searched all day without success; found next day with herd of cows at Remoncourt - impossible for small child to get so far

timeline.subject: Margueritte femme Claude Martin
timeline.details: Procureur fiscal of comté de Blamont asks prévôt to get echevins to conduct secret enquiry

timeline.subject: Witnesses continued
timeline.details: Witness depositions continued after 5 year gap

timeline.subject: Margueritte femme Claude Martin
timeline.details: Substitut for procureur fiscal asks for arrest, interrogation, and confrontations

timeline.subject: Margueritte femme Claude Martin
timeline.details: Confrontations with witnesses - denied all charges, made reproaches to some witnesses

timeline.subject: Margueritte femme Claude Martin
timeline.details: Procureur fiscal asks for question ordinaire et extraordinaire; complains about blasphemies

timeline.subject: Margueritte femme Claude Martin
timeline.details: First day of torture - thumbscrews and strappado; refused to confess; ordered to be shaved

timeline.subject: Margueritte femme Claude Martin
timeline.details: Second day - racked again (marginal note: contre le droit), given tortillons, put on strappado with stones; refused to confess; sent back to prison for debility

timeline.subject: Margueritte femme Claude Martin
timeline.details: Procureur fiscal admits she purged herself of witchcraft; asks for punishment for blasphemy: amende honorable, whipping, and banishment

timeline.subject: Margueritte femme Claude Martin
timeline.details: Change de Nancy agrees she should be renvoyée on witchcraft; for blasphemy, court should point out enormity and order her to seek pardon

timeline.subject: Margueritte femme Claude Martin
timeline.details: Formal sentence from court at Blamont ordering that she be renvoyée

methods: strappado with stones tied to feet
torture.restrictions: Marginal notes protest that second day of torture was 'contre le droict et la pratique' - multiple violations noted

prior_accusations.context: Said accused should be taken to prison with other prisoners from Leintrey accused of witchcraft

notable_quotes.speaker: Margueritte femme Claude Martin (accused)
notable_quotes.french: qu'elle ne craindoit ny dieu ny diable, et qu'elle estoit aussy nette du crime de sortilege que nre Seigneur
notable_quotes.english: that she feared neither God nor devil, and that she was as clean of the crime of witchcraft as our Lord
notable_quotes.context: Said on way to Blamont; cited as blasphemy

notable_quotes.speaker: Margueritte femme Claude Martin (accused)
notable_quotes.french: they did her as great wrong as had been done to Virgin Mary
notable_quotes.context: When told Godat's wife suspected her; marginal note of outrage at comparison

notable_quotes.speaker: Henry Claudon (witness 8)
notable_quotes.french: que c'estoit eulx qui luy donnoit ung mauvais fame, que c'estoit ung beau chappeau qu'ils mettoient sur la teste de ses enfans que c'estoit assé pour la faire devenir genoxe et que sy il luy survenoit quelque chose qu'elle en donneroit la charge a luy deposant
notable_quotes.english: that it was they who gave her a bad reputation, that it was a fine hat they put on her children's heads, that it was enough to make her go mad, and that if anything happened to her she would give the blame to him (the witness)
notable_quotes.context: Threat from accused to witness after he protected Françoise

notable_quotes.speaker: Claudon Marchal (witness 9)
notable_quotes.french: qu'il estoit bien hautain mais qu'en peu de temps son cacquant luy rabaisseroit
notable_quotes.english: that he was very arrogant but in a short time his pride would be lowered

notable_quotes.speaker: Margueritte femme Claude Martin (accused)
notable_quotes.french: qu'elle ne se lamente sy croit que son enfant n'estoit perdu, et que s'il estoit bien signé du signe de la croix il failloit croire qu'il retrouveroit aydant dieu qu'il estoit ausy seure aux champs qu'a la ville
notable_quotes.english: that she should not lament, she believed the child was not lost, and if it was well signed with the sign of the cross one should believe it would be found, God willing, that it was as safe in the fields as in the town
notable_quotes.context: To Jehenne after her child disappeared; considered suspicious knowledge

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon veuve Claudon Jacquemin (witness 4, sister)
notable_quotes.french: que sy elle le savoit elle parleroit a elle d'une bonne façon
notable_quotes.english: that if she knew who did it, she would speak to her in a good way
notable_quotes.context: Witness's response when accused asked who gave her son the illness

notable_quotes.speaker: Margueritte femme Claude Martin (accused)
notable_quotes.french: ung pauvre bon homme ne desirant de arrester a aultruy
notable_quotes.english: a poor good man not wishing to trouble others
notable_quotes.context: Describing her husband's unwillingness to take legal action when she was called witch

notable_quotes.speaker: Margueritte femme Claude Martin (accused)
notable_quotes.context: Describing the family of Demenge Bon Claude, explaining why she discouraged her son from marrying his daughter; claimed his father Jean was banished from duchy as witch

relationships.evidence_text: married to present husband some 27 years
father was Pierson de Waxaville, laboureur
had been married to Didier de Vacourt

economic_context.details: Multiple disputes: debt with Allison Hellenix over money owed and daughter's work; dispute with Mongin Godat over debt and field sowing; inheritance dispute with sister Jennon veuve Claudon Jacquemin; wage dispute with Jehenne femme Demenge Gadel over reaping prices. Accused kept a tavern. Some witnesses mentioned economic value of lost animals (cow worth 30 francs). Witnesses noted accused's interest in property of nephews as 'richest young men in village'.

Witness returning from there heard women mocking chapelet; also where witness went to reap and child disappeared

historical_context.military_details: Soldiers mentioned as expected/feared; accused claimed she fell while trying to hide cock from soldiers in hayloft 12 years before trial
economic_hardship_indicators: value of animals noted (cow worth 30 francs)
religious_calendar_references: end of winter (when cattle incident occurred)

officials_named.name: procureur fiscal of comté de Blamont

prior_legal_disputes.description: Demenge Conna called accused witch; they were called before prévôt who made them forgive each other and make peace
Demenge Michel Valence called her witch; husband had to make reparation with written document
Simon Marie called her witch when drunk; begged pardon in house of Demenge Parmentier and in presence of prévôt; she was promised 'acte de justice' but did not get it
prior_legal_disputes.outcome: pardon begged, promised legal document but not received

legal_context.redress_outcome: Multiple instances: (1) Demenge Jacquemin called her witch but she sought no redress; (2) Thiebault's wife called her witch but did not seek redress; (3) Mongin Godat called her witch and told her to get out - she made no complaint; (4) Simon Marie case - promised acte de justice but did not receive it. Generally did not seek redress except in Simon Marie case.
legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: Imprisoned before interrogation; after torture on Sept 19 ordered to be shaved 'affin de pouvoir facillement tirer la verité d'elle, et empescher que l'ennemy ne s'y cache et l'empesche de dire la verité'; after torture on Sept 20 sent back to prison 'pour sa debillité'

hearsay_chains.content: accusations by Demenge de Conna and wife over death of daughter, and by Margueritte over death of first husband

hearsay_chains.source: woman from Metz who practiced divination
hearsay_chains.content: told daughter that illness had been given by woman to whom they refused a cauldron
said accused should be taken to prison with others
heard accused said however much treatment he had, he would never see so well again
heard 3 women making mocking remarks about chapelet
heard someone say devil had caused accused to fall onto threshing floor
within 3 weeks heard of her reputation

emotional_state_notes: comparison to Virgin Mary - marginal note of outrage
pretended to be unable to speak after torture
finally made renunciation 'as if by force'
said she was so upset she might have made blasphemous statements

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: Claudon Marchal was always quarrelling and had long sought to dishonour her
Demenge Grand Colas was a liar and 'renyeur de debte' (denier of debt)

extraction_metadata.notes: This is an exceptionally detailed trial record with 23 witness depositions spanning 5 years (1607-1612). Notable features: (1) Accused was RELEASED after withstanding extensive torture without confessing - very rare outcome; (2) Five-year gap between initial depositions (1607) and resumption of trial (1612); (3) Multiple marginal notes protesting illegal torture practices; (4) Extensive catalog of harms including deaths of multiple children (often via food), animal deaths, and property damage; (5) Rich detail on quarrels, debts, inheritance disputes; (6) Accused made blasphemous comparisons to Christ and Virgin Mary; (7) Multiple witnesses mention Doctor Odet at Blamont diagnosing witchcraft; (8) Pilgrimage to Beau Bernard mentioned multiple times as cure; (9) One witness page missing (witness 3 incomplete); (10) Procureur fiscal sought punishment for blasphemy (whipping, banishment) even after acquittal on witchcraft; (11) Change de Nancy rejected this and ordered only admonishment; (12) Multiple instances where accused did not seek legal redress when called witch. This trial provides exceptional insight into a survivor's case and the limits of torture.
